awd_titl_txt: Integrating Computer Science into the Elementary Curriculum in Culturally Relevant Ways: A Researcher-Practitioner-Partnership in Native-American Serving Districts in Wyoming
awd_abstract_narration:
Native American communities are underrepresented in computer science professions, and there is a need educationally to make this domain relevant to Native cultures. The American Institutes for Research--in collaboration with the Wyoming Department of Education, three Wyoming school districts on the Wind River Reservation, and BootUp Professional Development--will write, pilot, and refine a curriculum for grades 3-5 that integrates computer science and Wyoming Indian Education for All social studies standards in culturally relevant ways. In 2022, this curriculum is being published by Wyoming Department of Education for all districts in the state to use as they implement newly mandated Wyoming computer science and Indian Education for All social studies standards. The project is also making the curriculum available to other districts and states nationwide that serve Native students with suggestions about how to adapt the curricular materials to make them locally relevant to the populations they are serving. The team is providing a report for local and state education agencies with "lessons learned" on how to integrate computer science education with other elementary school content in Grades 3-5. In this way, the project not only is broadening participation in computer science for historically underserved Native American students living on the Wind River Reservation in Wyoming but also is reaching Native American students throughout Wyoming and the nation. 

Computer science education has been focused largely on policies and curricula for secondary students. Elementary school teachers often express concern that they do not have time to teach computer science, given competing pressures to teach other subjects. The proposed study will generate curricular resources that integrate computer science with social studies standards, thus providing a solution to this challenge. BootUp Professional Development is authoring the curriculum, and the American Institutes for Research is leading a networked improvement community focused on refining the curriculum to ensure that it is usable, useful, and culturally relevant. Participants in the networked improvement community include the Wyoming Department of Education, 25 classroom teachers from three Wyoming districts, staff from BootUp Professional Development and American Institutes for Research researchers. In 2022, the project is disseminating curricular resources that other districts nationwide can adapt and use and will also produce a model for how to design an integrated curriculum in a way that is culturally relevant. In addition, the project is demonstrating how participating in both professional development and a networked improvement community that focuses on formative feedback can result in higher levels of teacher self-efficacy, teacher content and pedagogical knowledge, and, ultimately, student mastery of computer science content standards. This project is funded by CS for All.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Indigenous students have been historically underrepresented in computer science (CS) education in K-12 settings. The Wind River Elementary Computer Science (WRECS) Collaborative is a research-practice-partnership (RPP) that began in fall 2019. The WRECS Collaborative included teachers and leaders from three school districts serving Eastern Shoshone and Northern Arapaho communities on the Wind River Reservation. It also included BootUp Professional Development (BootUp PD), American Institutes for Research (AIR), and the Wyoming Department of Education (WDE).

The WRECS Collaborative originated to meet expressed needs of districts, teachers, communities, and families on the Wind River Reservation. Districts and teachers faced challenges related to implementing new computer science (CS) standards in Wyoming because most teachers had not received preparation or training to offer instruction in CS.  Community members - including tribal leaders, family members, and teachers - expressed a need for students to access high-quality CS education that would strengthen their cultural identities and traditions. From the perspective of the community, CS education could prepare students to serve tribal communities by pursuing postsecondary pathways involving coding. The subsequent sections provide more information about these district and community needs and explain how the WRECS Collaborative partners worked together to develop and implement solutions.

One way to broaden participation of Indigenous students is through the creation of CS lessons that simultaneously increase students’ understanding of and interest in CS while also sustaining their culture and language. In this study on the Wind River Reservation, researchers used observations of professional learning, teacher interviews, and reflection forms to answer questions about teachers’ and students’ experiences with implementing CS lesson plans. Findings indicate that implementing culturally sustaining CS education is a collective activity that requires professional development providers, curriculum developers, teachers, and students. Findings also indicate that, when provided with support and opportunities for collaboration, teachers can resolve challenges and successfully implement CS in elementary school settings. These findings have implications for practitioners interested in implementing CS education with Indigenous students and for policymakers interested in broadening access to CS education for students that have been historically marginalized.

Research Question

Findings

1. What challenges arise when elementary school teachers implement lessons that integrate CS standards and Indigenous language and culture?

1: Teachers negotiated implementation challenges at the student, teacher, and system levels. Challenges included differentiating materials for students, engaging students, lack of CS or Indigenous knowledge, need for collaboration, lack of support and time, teacher burnout, and technological difficulties.

2. What adaptations and enhancements arise while elementary school teachers implement lessons that integrate CS standards and Indigenous language and culture?

2a: Teachers adapted lessons to address the challenges and meet needs at the student, teacher, and systems level. They activated student background knowledge and allowed them to explore Scratch, partnered with other teachers, and used Scratch as a learning tool for teaching literacy and science.

2b: Teachers developed lessons and activities that expanded the WRECS Collaborative scope and extended its impact. They used Scratch as a tool for language reclamation, using computing tools beyond Scratch, and shared student’s work with the broader community.

3. In what ways did teachers report that WRECS activities supported student engagement and development?

3: Teachers described how the WRECS Collaborative activities showcased student strengths and supported peer collaboration.
